reviewText:
Both characters in this first-of-it's-kind movie were well drawn.  It's a first because it shows the S/M, D/s dynamic in a sympathetic, caring, humorous way; and it's a mainstream film ... not a parody or cautionary tale.
E. Edward Grey (an excellent James Spader reminiscent of "Sex, Lies and Videotape") could have used a little more background but that's quibbling.  Lee's character was simply marvelous from start to finish.  In my small hometown, a few people even applauded at the end.  We've come a long way.
Love comes in all sizes, and the discovery of that love makes an engrossing 144 minutes of film time. I've heard people say these two are "damaged."  Really?  But aren't we all?  And how lovely and whimsical to find another who understands us so well.
Lee (Maggie Gyllenhaal) blossoms from a repressed, obsessive, unhappy girl into a self-assured woman all because a strange, obsessive, largely unhappy man sees in her the need to be .... herself ... a submissively strong woman who likes to be spanked, restrained, and ordered around.  As long as she knows her submission is understood, she is liberated in the true sense of that term.  She becomes the powerful one ... all because she accepts who she is. Acceptance and love.  Isn't that what most of us aspire to?
I loved the scene where Lee tries to do the impossible: make a cup of coffee for the new boss who casually demands it.  A truly submissive person will understand that scene on a very deep level.
I'll see this again before it leaves my local theater. And can't wait to buy the DVD when it's available.  It's a "feel good" movie with an irresistible twist! :)
This movie is not for everyone; but I wish I could say it was.  It deals with all the relevant themes of a good, complex love story.  It just adds a new level ---- and one that's been around in the shadows for a few decades.
Exciting, sexy, naughty, the acting was superb!!  I would recommend this movie to any adult who is uninhibited.

I can see how some people would be impressed by this movie, but I wasn't. It moved way too slow for me and I grew annoyed instead of intrigued by the characters. There were just way too many gimmicks for me to sit through! While the rest of the theater laughed at the pathetic title character's antics, I looked at my watch. I walked out of the theater soon after watching the scene where Lee and her boyfriend was having dinner at a resturaunt that looked like an adolecent girl's jewelry store. James Spader deserves better than this.

Heard the buzz about this one weeks ago (LOVE the promotional poster). The theatre in NYC was 90% full, 2 or 3 people left in the middle of it, but not me. I like to watch the envelope get pushed.
The film seems to be an essay on "psychologically broken" people
finding each other and muddling thru "normal life." Practically
everyone on screen has had some form of emotional crippling which
keeps them isolated from everyday society. But this is far from a
"downer," because amidst the angst, there are subtle laughs -- the strange behavior can make you chuckle at the oddest situations...
I hate to give away too much plot, but if you enjoy movies that keep you thinking while it plays with your emotions AND challenges your ideas of acceptable behavior, give it a shot.
The acting is fascinating, with the female lead (Maggie Gyllenhaal) giving off sparks of extreme courage -- not many women would have taken on a role like this.
I loved Cronenberg's "Crash" because it was a psychological spinning wheel:you could never clearly predict what anyone was doing or thinking. This runs along the same lines.
Did I like it? I was in its spell, following it wherever it went,
and most importantly, I was never bored (a lot like "Mullholland
Drive")--so yeah, I liked it. Would I see it again & again? Probably not. Would I recommend it? Only to the adventurous -- most regular moviegoers would find this perverse/silly/pointless
or just plain "bad." (Believe me, it is none of those)
Throughout the film, I kept thinking "I can't believe a movie like this came out of Hollywood !" It's someone's dark little secret fantasy put up on a big screen for all to see, and the girl's final close-up may sum up the filmaker's message in a nutshell. "Yeah, and what are YOU looking at....?"

I have to review this after reading other reviews.  I thought this movie was very well done.  I certainly don't think it will appeal to everyone, but those that it does, it speaks. *spoilers ahead*  I don't really think that it's accurate to comment on this as BDSM - just finished reading one review who says that you have to suspend a lot of disbelief about Lee's inexperience and Mr. Grey's involvement with her b/c no Dom would ever involve themselves with someone with no experience.  I'm no expert, but I have to disagree.  I never got the impression that he considered himself a Dom, and was entering into contracts or agreements with submissives.  I thought it was more realistic in the fact that, you know, I think we all have things that are a little weird about us, especially when it comes to sexual quirks, and we don't always understand them, and many of us spend our entire lives fighting them and thinking we're strange or wrong.  Not to mention we don't start out as experts.  There are going to be experiences that lead us to these discoveries, and it will take time before fully understanding them.  So I took this plot as Mr. Grey trying to repress this side of himself, he punished himself for it, and self-loathing was eating him up, but of course he's only human and gives in to the temptation.  Lee, obviously, was totally new to it, so it was very clear that on her side it was about discovery.  So I didn't suspend any disbelief, this is kind of exactly the way I would imagine that people with these types of tastes discover them. Of course, it's a movie, so I suppose the suspended disbelief might be on the happy ending, but still, in my mind, this was more realistic than a typical movie.  Excellent work, from all sides.  The sexual tension was very well done, and while at times the scenes were a bit bizarre, it just added to the appeal.
The writing was fabulous and James Spader knocked it out of the park.  These actors made me feel that this was real. And of course the music was brilliant.
For better or worse, a more accurate portrayal of this type of relationship than people think.

But, somehow they see a needing quality to release all the pain and angry and basically help each other together.

Can a masochist find true happiness?  Apparently so, if she finds just the right sadist.  Maggie Gyllenhaal is terrific, but she was a bit too plotting for a submissive personality and, ultimately, at a critical moment does something out of character.  Spader clearly has the upper hand.  He has insight into what Gyllenhaal thinks and craves, but he is almost too remorseful to sustain the relationship.  In short, the principal characters are probably not representative of real sado-masochists.  They are too functional for that.  Still, the movie makes an effective plea for diversity.  If I had known what it was about, I would probably not have watched it.  However, it is very entertaining, offbeat love story.

Been many years since this movie came out....before Spader was in Boston Legal and its popular spin off with William Shatner....and long before his bravo performance as the mysterious billionaire "Red" in NBC's TV show "the Blacklist"....here he plays a crazy Attorney (I know it's been done before--for several crazy Attorneys check out "LA Law" "Better Call Saul" and the excellent movie "And Justice For All") with a separately crazy Maggie Gyllenthall as his neophyte legal secretary. We go to strange places conference room clients should never see....the bit about typing mistakes and "punishment thereto" will haunt you...plus did you ever get a draft copy of a document brought to you by your secretary (scantily dressed) and crawling on all fours?" No---just checking-- neither have I....interesting dual character study but still you are going to crazytown with these two........................

Most of the time it seems when people look at/read/hear about relationships like the one my Master and I share all they see is the 'scary' aspects, but this movie highlights that M/s is so much more than sadomasochistic sex (or any other fear-mongering stereotype). Our relationship is based on love, connection, and clarity of expectations. The submissive in this movie learns to anticipate the needs of the Dominant, and modifies her behavior to please both of them (though she still occasionally engages in the game of "Poke the Sadist". All in mutual fun though). The Dominant recognizes the needs of the submissive and sets clear boundaries and protocols to be followed that are mutually beneficial. Their relationship is built on love, respect. and "the little things" - just like any other healthy relationship. It's great to see that highlighted mainstream. Kudos.

Hi, being a submissive I was expecting a little bit more in my opinion but overall it was a good movie.  I did not realize it was a comedy and it pleasantly surprised me.  I did like the movie but it only depicts a potential example of a D/s sexual relationship. For instance, my Dom and I do not utilize physical discipline for the very reason depicted in the movie. Since I am a masochist, impact play (eg: spanking) is a motivator for disobedience not a deterrent within our dynamic. In other D/s relationship dynamics, this may not be the case though. The majority of Doms want a Power Exchange not a power struggle. Most Doms know Themselves before accepting a submissive. IMO, it is highly irresponsible if not dangerous for a Dom not to know Him/Herself beforehand. They need to know They can control Themselves before controlling someone else.. Mr. Grey did not know Himself and the movie depicts that a Dom not knowing Himself can be harmful to the sub. Of course, by the end He discovered Himself so it was a happy ending. What I LOVED about Maggie was that she found herself in her submission and it was freeing<===This is accurate for a percentage of subs---a feeling of completeness.  D/s is a very personal journey of self discovery and living your life being true to yourself.  Every D/s dynamic is unique because each person in the dynamic has their own personality, limits, needs and kinks. So, depicting accurate BDSM would be difficult in a film because it is so varied and vast. BTW, some  D/s relationships do not even include sex within their dynamic. What I did not like was the portrayal of the characters being mentally ill (stereo-type of BDSM). In the real world, people into BDSM come from every walk of life and socio-economic background including people who may have physical or mental illnesses or who are perfectly healthy and sane.  What I also love-LOVED was that Maggie RESEARCHED and READ all she could on BDSM.....she educated herself.  Becoming knowledgeable of BDSM is very important in order to understand various types of kink, limits, power exchange and most importantly the SAFETY aspect.  I give the movie a grade of B.  For me, the Submission of Emma Marx trilogy is a more realistic depiction of a D/s relationship especially since she uses her safe word during a scene.

One of those rare gems of film making. Take a taboo subject play it as human comedy and you shed some light on the human condition. Now, there is no political movement promoting that SMBD is the sexual freedom we have all been missing and should immediately embrace like lesbianism and homosexuality. It seems that the social engineers of the past eight years have over looked SM & BD as lifestyles for everyone. Give them time and I expect that the political correct crowd will be pushing our noses in it.
However, in the meantime someone made a movie, a very good movie; a movie made damn near perfect for the talents of James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal. Its got pathos and bathos, which makes it watchable for those who have no prurient interest in the subject.
BTY, human comedy is about common people who through the course of the play or movie overcome certain life problems to the improvement of their lives. Hence, that is the basic message of the movie.
If you are in naughty mood, and want to see a naughty romance, this is a fun watch.  Great actors, clever writing, and simple one or two room type low budget film.  However, good fun for late night.

Brief plot.  A sort of crazy girl with a troubled family applies for her first job as a secretary.  She ends up becoming attracted to her boss, who is a lawyer.  But the sexual attraction isn't a typical movie display of sex.  There are some taboo twists.  I definitely couldn't predict what would happen next, and that is probably why it is sort of difficult to not watch the whole movie; it certainly is unique.

I wasn't sure what I was going to be watching. The production quality wasn't perfect, but not terrible either.  Limited scenery.  As I said about the plot: it was a bit strange.  Some of the scenes were sort of slow and drawn out with seemingly no intent of portraying anything thought provoking.  It is as if the director just wanted to waste some time.  But.  On the other hand.  I relate to the female characters form of self abuse in the beginning, and some of the dialogue explaining reasoning behind it was to me, psychologically very correct.  Not complete but correct.  But for the record, I won't be making any typos, I'm just not into the result.  Enjoy.

Does a great job at demonstrating how the main character could plausibly get from A to Z as the story demands, but the film promises a lot more than it delivers. The gratuitous nudity at the end should have happened far earlier and both genders should have been involved not just Gyllenhaal. The fact that it's all too traditional in that sense is a sad commentary on our American fear of, and immaturity with our sexuality in this society. And Spader is far too good-looking--to be the one seen only shirtless for 2-seconds at the end of the film, while Gyllenhaal gets viewed in full frontal. There are 2 genders in the world dear filmmakers, and the female of the species makes up the larger of those halves (we are 51%). Fans of BDSM will note that this is arguably the original material upon which 50 Shades was based, and is actually much better, and more palatable, in reaching its goals than the Shades books or movies. Given the age of Gyllenhaal's character and her sexual inexperience, this storyline is a more plausible set up, but still quite a huge stretch. Why? Because most Doms in the Lifestyle (Spader's character isn't and doesn't claim to be throughout 90% of the movie) would never enter into a dom/sub arrangement of any kind with someone who is sexually inexperienced. That's dangerous, and it's courting legal trouble, as well. Doesn't happen in the real world. So expect to suspend a great deal of your disbelief if you watch this. I'm reviewing this with an eye to some what viewer expectation will be here because of the increased mainstream interest and acceptance of BDSM since Shades. Performances by both actors are outstanding. The movie certainly has some lighter moments in it that make the content of their mutual character's psychological and emotional troubles easier to see, understand, and think about within the context of our fairly rigid social culture, where our expectations are shackled with overtones of religious extremism in the mainstream. The downside to this movie is that it could have been a MUCH sexier film without needing to go any further with clothing removal than it did (hardly any as it is), but it does suffer from the scrutiny of the time period and cultural expectations of our society. Highly recommended movie! (Disclaimer: I'm naturally biased toward freedom of expression, freedom of speech (including sexuality) I'm also looking at this movie not just as a former filmmaker, but also from the perspective of its impact upon us culturally and socially, and what it does to advance (or diminish) sexual expression as a valid form of communication. This advances at least the dialogue about sexuality and pain, if not the expression, but other films are needed to become part of the mainstream for us to reach advancement of expression around sexuality. Ultimately every movie or book or painting is a piece of art and the viewers reaction says more about them and their state of being than about the art itself. Without the art however, we have nothing but blank slate, and it's hard to have a dialogue of any kind without the art. Worth the almost 2 hours of your time.

Between James Spader's exquisite take as an experienced member of the BDSM scene (as a bottom and top, from hints in the movie, though his role is dominant throughout the film) and Maggie Gyllenhaal's discovery as his submissive, I loved this quirky take on "BDSM For Beginners".

BDSM and the idea that people choose to connect with each other in unconventional ways is easy for many of us to accept. Irrespective of that, the way this story is unfolded is unusual and unsettling. When we are first introduced to the Maggie character she is suffering from a terrible family situation. Her father is mentally ill and an alcoholic, and this--we are led to believe--is the cause of wounds she is intentionally inflicting on herself. Our sympathies are enlisted for Spader's tyrannical attorney specifically because he cares about Maggie and wants her to stop hurting herself. There is a turning point when Maggie drops her kit of knives and scissors into the river, signaling that she is cured of this sickness, thanks to Spader. She becomes so enamored with Spader's tyranny, however, that she starts inflicting more pain on herself, paddling her rear with a hairbrush in private and fantasizing that he is inflicting other painful punishments. By the end of the story, once the two have married, she's showing him all the scars from the wounds she gave herself before meeting him--with pride and joy. What? Should we revisit the impressions we formed during the first hour of the film and disconnect Maggie's self-abuse from her father? When she tossed the knives and scissors away--was that not really a turning point? Does she still need to feel pain, for reasons that have nothing to do with her father? Or are we supposed to see that the desire for pain, which was initially pathological, has now been turned into something wonderful because it's associated with love? The story strategy is much more devious than it at first appears. And the layers of dark humor and sentimentality further complicate our emotional reactions. A very interesting movie. Truly peculiar.

Fifty Shades delves further into the background of its Mr. Grey (at least in the books-- it remains to be seen how much can be covered in a standard-length film), and clearly there will be far more attention paid to the intimate encounters, but Secretary keeps the dynamics of the relationship squarely as the central focus (and rather than a reluctant/ambivalent submissive a.k.a. Ana, Lee Holloway actually winds up "pursuing" HER Mr. Grey. When I first read Fifty Shades my first thought was how it just couldn't be coincidence -- another Mr. Grey? So it would seem-- but don't overlook his predecessor, or the quirky fun of this film!

This film does something no other film dealing with this subject matter has: made it safe and accessible, instead of scary or parodistic.  Instead of making it a grand spectacle, the film does a good job of creating interesting characters you care about first, THEN creates an intriguing world where their behavior and relationship is meaningful.  It shows the complexities of such a relationship: although Gyllenhaal's character is clearly submissive, she still finds ways to exert control.  And while Spader's character is an obsessive control freak, he displays compassion and care, while dealing with the internal loss of control that comes with falling in love.

I've had this movie sitting around for months, but the mixed reviews I'd read kept me from getting around to watching it. Last night, my boyfriend was going through my movies and asked me what it was about. All I could remember from the description were "BDSM" and "Maggie Gyllenhaal", but that was enough for us to give it a  shot. We started watching, very aware that it might turn out to be weird rather than honest. We were both pleasantly surprised.
James Spader is fantastic, giving a performance with as much reactionary face contorting as Tim Roth in Four Rooms but without the camp. You can tell that this was based on a short story because it feels like the world in which it takes place is in a pocket universe, where even interactions with the real world focus almost entirely around the two main characters.
Maggie Gyllenhaal's performance is equally amazing, completely transforming her into Lee. My one problem with her performance is that all throughout the movie I wanted to tell her to stand up straight, but that's just because her shy slouch looks painful.
Almost every scene is powerfully raw and honest, thanks in large part to Spader's full immersion into his character. When he's talking with Gyllenhaal, you can't look away- but it's when no one can see him but the camera that his performance really shines. It's obvious that his character knows exactly HOW to be dominant in exactly the way she needs him to be, but when he's alone he has so much trouble with WHY and this is written clearly on his face.
The BDSM is light, and hinted (especially in a hilarious montage in the middle of the movie) more than shown, but it doesn't seem that the director was shying away from it- more like they're just showing you what is necessary to tell the story.
That brings me to the director. He managed to squeeze more talent, more emotion out of every scene than I thought possible. It's been ten years since this came out and I have never heard his name before, but I think I should have by now. He's clearly fantastic.
My only problem with the movie is that in the first scene in the office, one of the three steadycam operators sort of failed at keeping the camera steady.
All in all, this has got to be one of my favourite movies of all time.
great movie and love the characters. the reluctant dom, james spader, and the eager sub, maggie gillinall, are funny and loveable at the same time.

Oh, sorry, this is Edward Grey, not Christian! In the aftermath of Fifty Shades the world of D/S has become a tad more mainstream. This film does a wonderful job of walking the fine line between satire and psychological thriller. These are not two people playing with a spanking or two, far from it. She has a history of serious problems with cutting, among other things, and is the last person who should be playing with the submissive role to a strange lawyer who has a penchant for domination (this is not play, folks). The sense of danger is palpable in every frame, and you are never sure if and when this dangerous liason will spiral out of control into something far more dangerous, even life threatening. Maggie Gyllenhall is absolutely perfect as the secretary who gets what she needs, and perhaps more, balanced on the edge of a precipice that could lead to madness. James Spader plays this as well as Nicholson did with "The Shining"...the comparison will be clear when you se the film. I could not take my eyes off the screen as the spring tightened, and I suspect you will feel the same. Be clear, though, that this is not a play ful romp, far from it. It is a psychological thriller not a sex tape. For a slightly more edgy take on D/S from 1986, see Kim Bassinger and Mickey Rourke in the classic 9 1/2 Weeks (Original Uncut Uncensored Version). By the way, there are several versions, some edited, so if you wish to see and judge the real thing, be sure to get the uncut version.

Maggie Gyllenhaal exploded onto the scene in the early aughts, and it was her devilishly stunning turn in the kinky office drama `Secretary' that got her the bulk of her acclaim and spearheaded her to the front of the pack as far as talented young stars were concerned.  I'm still completely floored by the way she crafts such a complex character and still manages to make her feel so simple.

The film is adapted from the short story by Mary Gaitskill.  It tells the story of a young woman named Lee who is from a very defunct family and certainly suffers because of it.  On the outset of the film she is being released from institutional therapy and takes a job as a secretary for a lawyer named Mr. Grey.  Almost immediately, their relationship turns toward S&M.  Both parties are obviously compliant with the idea and looking for the opportunity, and so when it presents itself they take full advantage.  The relationship seems to have nowhere to go but downhill, but `Secretary' takes a surprising turn in direction as it defies logic and creates a home for these emotionally crippled individuals.

Spader is wonderful, truly embracing his dominant quality (and the comparisons to `sex, lies and videotape' are warranted) but it is Gyllenhaal who completely owns this film.  The way she filters through all the stages of her character's growth is flawless, and the way she communicates such yearning with her eyes (and the way she `takes it') is just marvelously rendered with great finesse.  She conveys emotions that hit hard and help to add depth to the subject at hand.  That is another thing that is so commendable about `Secretary' is that it never appears to prod or poke fun or dismiss this `situation' as a mere gag or gimmick, but it is always presented in a realistic and accessible way.  This film is far from judgmental, and while the ending can and probably should be seen as a fantastical representation of a day-dream, it is constructed in a way that feels authentic and `appropriate'.

I'll echo the sentiments regarding the non-existent backstory for Mr. Grey.  It would have really been nice to add some depth or color to his character.  Lee's character is broken down for us in many ways, either obviously or within Gyllenhaal's presentation, but Mr. Grey is ambiguous to the point where it feels like a plot hole almost.  Alas, this is still a smart and witty look at a serious situation and it sports one of the best breakthrough performances of the aughts.

The comparisons to that `Fifty Shades of Grey' trash is beyond me.

All in all this is a lighthearted serious/comedy. The hardcore BDSM types will be disappointed and the vanilla types will be scratching their heads. If they'd put the opening sequence at the end it might have been 5 stars.

A solid four stars. But better as a rental, than a purchase.

Caution: this review contains spoilers.  Read at your own risk.
I loved this film enough to buy it on DVD which I so very rarely do.  I've only purchased 3 or 4 movies in my entire life.  This was the best of them.
The movie depicts a young woman, Lee, who self-mutilates and ends up in a mental hospital.  Upon release she is far from cured because no one has understood that her proclivity for self-mutilation is really a cry for love not help.  The love that she is seeking is not the vanilla love that a strange friend (Peter) offers her.  Lee needs to be understood and in order to do that she has to meet someone who realizes that Lee really wants a BDSM relationship where she can play out her submissive desires for discipline and, when needed, punishment.  Under the over watchful eye of attorney E. Edward Grey, Lee finds her mentor and eventually her Dominant lover.
It seems that neither Lee nor Edward really understands their own BDSM needs but as the story unfolds, they come to understand what they each lack and what the other can supply.  When Edward fires Lee, we see that he does not really understand his own insecurity.  Far from being a self-assured Dominant, Edward is not really sure how he feels about himself or about Lee.  Lee, on the other hand, hesitates for as long as it takes to don a wedding gown, and then has a moment of clarity.
She runs out of the gown fitting knowing what and who she wants.  Peter who has proposed marriage would be a ho hum lover and husband sending Lee right back to the sharp edges and cutting herself anew.  She knows that she wants and needs Edward and proceeds to run directly into his office and plants herself in his desk chair until he understands how much she loves him and how much he loves her.  It takes him three days of Lee not leaving the desk chair even to urinate.
In the end, Edward sees what Lee has discovered.  They are made for each other.  They may not be perfect but they are perfect for each other.
We should all be so lucky.

This has always been one of my favorite movies.  It gets mixed reviews, from the critics and from viewers and buyers.  It was ahead of its time just for shining a flashlight on some taboo topics.  People looking for typical Hollywood glitz and glamour or eye-popping special effects will be disappointed.  People looking for a sweaty, leather-clad S&M film with some dialogue thrown in just to help it pass as a movie...those people will be disappointed.  People looking for a movie that's different in its honesty and humanity will appreciate it.  It's a love story that skips all the drippy sweet gorgeous-guy-meets-perfect-girl; they don't immediately fall madly in fairy tale love and run off amid a shower of bird seed and ribbons to begin their perfect vanilla life together.  They don't engage in goofy, tripped-and-fell-into-my-dream-date sitcom antics that saturate your average romantic comedy.  Their mutual "interest" doesn't turn into a seedy, uncomfortable B-movie.  The film does a great job of casting off the entire dark image, and the sleazy stereotypes, and just telling a story about two people trying really hard to feel normal.  It's a lot less about sex, and a lot more about people just trying to be okay.  Under the sexual surface, it actually broaches some deep subjects shrouded in enough light humor that the realness doesn't weigh you down.

I've seen people characterize Spader's performance as "deadpan," "flat" and "emotionless," and criticize the movie for being slow and boring.  The man is playing an attorney, at work, in his law firm. Spader gives a great performance as a man torn between what he feels and what's acceptable. His "flat" affect is his character's forced act that he's just an average guy having an average day at the office. He's trying to appear professional, aloof, and disinterested--deadpan and emotionless--like he's supposed to.  Maggie's character is equally trying to her best to be accepted and convince the world she's normal--not just some nut job fresh out of the psych ward.  I've seen people rail against this portrayal of a creepy pervert taking advantage of a young psych patient, but that's not what happens here.  The point is she's not crazy--and neither is he.  They each have their own way of dealing, coping, and feeling, just like everyone else.  She watched daddy drink and mom get slapped around, and she coped by cutting.  Her dad's way of dealing-by-drinking is no better, and certainly not healthy, but since it's also not wierd or morbid it's accepted.  Of course it's not okay for Lee to cut herself, or for Mr. Grey to spank total strangers for making typos--suppressed feelings almost always manifest themselves in inappropriate behaviors. Once these two find each other, and start expressing instead of supressing themselves as part of a consensual adult relationship, the inappropriate coping mechanisms stop and they finally become the "normal" people they've been pretending to be all along. He goes to the office like an average guy, she settles into being the average housewife, and they do their thing at home where it's completely appropriate.  No more cutting, no more changing secretaries like underwear...they're healthy, they're happy, and they didn't even need rehab.  Once he can stop pretending, Spader's "flat, deadpan" persona gives way to feeling and passion--even tenderness-- but thankfully without the sappy, mushy, "romance" typical of most love stories. This movie is deeper than a "dark comedy," and way more relatable than a fairy-tale romance.  It's truer and cleaner than the S&M flick some people were hoping for.  If you're looking for a B&D guy movie, you'll have to look elsewhere.  If you're looking for the usual hearts-and-flowers chick-flick, this isn't it. If you want a break from the ordinary and a love story that's not so sweet it hurts your teeth, this delivers. It's not a film for everyone, but people who don't enjoy the lifestyle can still enjoy the movie and may even end up getting ideas.

This is a beautiful and unconventional little movie.  Surreal yet profound it digs around in the heart of sexual emotion, desire and love, and perhaps most unusually, devotion.  It never falls prey to stereotype of pre-prescribed ideas of what those things are and often seems to be exploring them for the first time.  What a breath of fresh air.  I loved this movie. Dynomite performances by Spader (who's still got that tweaked charm) and Maggie Gyllenhaal, who's very moving and very likable.  Finally though this movie's got a sense of humor under all the rage of desire on a low boil.  It's almost a dark comedy, if not for the fact that it touches on some very real issues of the heart. Bravo!

It's too bad that Amazon allows ratings only up to 5 stars. I would give "Secretary" at least 7 stars. It has easily become my all-time favorite movie.

The principal characters are Lee Holloway (Maggie Gyllenhaal) and E. Edward Grey (James Spader).  Lee is a young woman who cuts herself when stressed.  Mr. Grey is her employer, an obsessive-compulsive, with a seemingly mean streak which masks his attraction to Lee.  As the plot unfolds their relationship evolves, to put it mildly.

The theme of Secretary is dominance/submission, and there are scenes of spanking, self-stimulation, and some nudity. Fair warning to any yahoos out there who think that women should be kept barefoot and pregnant, and slapped around: you'll find this movie disappointing  -- spend your money on a six-pack instead.

Fair advice also to any feminists out there who might pre-judge that "Secretary" serves only to gratify the aforementioned yahoos: I would urge you to see this movie and judge for yourself. You'll need to keep an open mind as you watch, but if you can suspend judgment you may see a beautiful love story about two wounded people finding one another.

I won't say much here about the plot, which I found highly erotic despite the often light-hearted tone of the movie. The most intensely erotic scene, for me, was the one labeled "Insight" on the scene selection menu. Erotic? Lee and Mr. Grey merely talk, they keep their clothes on, and don't even touch one another, although they sit just a bit too close and make a bit too much eye contact. The essential action of this scene is that Mr. Grey, having discovered that Lee cuts herself when stressed, persuades her to stop. Well, actually, he commands her to stop. Lee's emotions flash through timidity, apprehension, eagerness, shyness, subtle flirtatiousness, self-deprecating humor, acquiescence, insight, resoluteness, and growing respect for both herself and Mr. Grey. The sexual tension in this scene is palpable, and when it ends one senses that the fireworks are about to begin. Ms. Gyllenhaal's performance here (and indeed through the entire movie) is pitch-perfect. She manages to convey Lee's feelings with subtleties of voice, eyes, mouth, hands, head tilt, posture, breathing, the lump in her throat, you name it. Gyllenhaal effortlessly manages to look comedic, optimistic in spite of her problem, cute, or drop-dead gorgeous, whatever the moment calls for. It's magic; in my opinion, the only other actress who comes close to Gyllenhaal's skills is Helen Mirren.

James Spader, whose role calls for great subtlety, is also perfect as Mr. Grey, as are the entire cast of supporting characters. Kudos also to Steven Shainberg for his vision and courage to create this film, and to Erin Cressida Wilson for the screen play adaptation of a short story by Mary Gaitskill. Although I don't usually pay attention to production details, I was greatly impressed by the camera work and editing. I also thought the music, especially the song "Chariots Rise" by Lizzie West, was great.

But it's Gyllenhaal who really owns this movie. After seeing Secretary, I wondered if perhaps she was a "one-trick pony," that is, great at playing only one particular type of character. So, I bought another feature film of hers, "Sherrybaby," in which she plays Sherry Swanson, a vulnerable but hard-bitten ex-con heroin addict with a quick temper and a habit of using sex to buy favors. Sherrybaby is a pretty gritty movie, but well worth seeing, and I would urge others to buy or rent it. If one didn't notice a facial resemblance, one might not realize that the same actress played both Lee Holloway and Sherry Swanson. Several professional critics opined that she deserved an Oscar nomination for that role.  Laughably, Gyllenhaal did finally get an Oscar nomination for her supporting role in Crazy Heart; she was of course very good in that movie, but her role simply didn't require great acting skills. Maybe some day Gyllenhaal will get the recognition she deserves.

One final note about the theme of Secretary: At least one other reviewer here commented that, although it was plausible for Lee Holloway to become a submissive, there was no explanation of why Mr. Grey became a dominant. I was also bothered by this at first, but then I concluded that because this movie was told from Lee's viewpoint, any background about Mr. Grey would have been a distraction. At first Mr. Grey seems like a domineering jerk, but as the movie unfolds we slowly discover that he, like Lee, is also a profoundly troubled soul. His empathy for Lee (albeit well disguised!) suggests that beneath his bluster he is also a submissive at heart, and that he gets satisfaction vicariously from his role as a dominant. This makes some sense, in accordance with the notion that in a successful dominant/submissive relationship, it is the submissive who is really in charge. I would refer you to the very final scene in Secretary.

Another enigmatic movie about that which makes the world turn. No, not money but sex and that practiced by those beyond the normal distribution curve of sexual behaviour. It's about a sheltered young woman released from a psychiatric institution, who seems repelled by the hypocrisy of her middle class environment. Her parents fight with verbal violence. She masks her emotional pain with the self-inflicted physical alternative; cutting herself but first seen with a scalding kettle being rested against her inner thigh. There was a flicker of a smile; perhaps that of self discovery. This motivates her to enter the world of adult work. She interviews for a job as a secretary. The interview is stilted. It's as if he has Aspergers syndrome; a sort of communication deficiency. "You are over-qualified. You'll be bored to death" he says. "I want to be bored... I like dull work" she retorts. There is a strong love of her father; his anguish triggering more cutting of herself. Yet all this is background to the main story; the unfolding relationship between her and her lawyer employer. This is a journey of emotional exploration with deviant sex as its embodiment. Love triumphs in an unexpected way.

"The Secretary" is an S&M story-book drama, destined to become a cult classic -  a "coming out" story of S&M in one's fantasy life, and as acted out in the world. It raises the issues of love, sex and the nature of pleasure, very graphically. The acting by James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal is superb, and the photography as well. The sound track of "relevant" popular songs accompany the dialogue and is well presented, too. Spader's role  is somewhat overdrawn, and is obviously written into the script, because he is such a fine actor. It contrasts beautifully with Gyllenhaal's "understated" persona. Seeing the scene played out in a luxurious law office lends the perfect bizarre quality to the theme of what lurks behind the appearance of normalcy, and perfection.

 Whether the main characters can keep their activity in bounds is the theme of the movie. A sub-theme is whether this "play" could be sustained indefinitely. Can the James Spader character keep his law practice intact and thriving, and can both characters achieve a relationship that sustains rather than destroys them? Answering these questions require the viewer to explore their own attitudes toward sex, love and pleasure and pain.

  The film also raise the issue of free will vs. compulsion in this very graphical way, and the issue of whether and how people can evolve in "healthy" ways. What constitutes "healthy" attitudes toward living and sexuality activity? If we say "healthy" is life-affirming and "unhealthy" is what is not, that's just begging the question. Such an answer puts labels on the issues of people's attitudes and behaviors toward themselves and others, given each person's inclinations. There are themes in philosophy and psychology courses here, graphically and beautifully portrayed and filmed. Credit or non-credit courses? you choose.

This is by far one of the best movies I've ever seen.  I'm not usually a big indie flick kind of person, but this move was SO well done, and the acting--holy crap, the acting.  I've never seen a movie with so little dialogue b/c it's not even needed--Spader and Gyllenhall's eyes, the very rare contact between them--says so much. There's this one scene where you can literally see Spader's character pull into himself and there's not a word said.  I mean, seriously, this movie has flaky layers of movie awesomeness.  I love the way it shows how a relationship--no matter the style--has to grow organically; too often relationships are defined and compared to what is actually their caricature:  from classic 50's hetero to BDSM harnesses and ball-gags to gay cowboys eating pudding--none of these represent the natural relationships that arise between two people.  What's relatable for anyone who's been in love is the same across the board: there's something in one that calls and the other answers (and vice versa).

Beautifully done; I just wish there were some guide besides the commentary to help out with all that symbolism and meaning there.  This movie should've won tons of awards.  Wish iTunes carried it.

`Secretary' is at film about the relationship between a secretary called Lee, played by Maggie Gyllenhaal, and her boss Edward played by James Spader. Initially it starts out as quite a sedate film with the boss being arrogant and rude, then he starts to humiliate her for minor work infractions, moving up to spanking, before their relationship takes a deeper turn. Much has been said about the sexual and deviant nature of this film and to be honest I have to say that is a lot of hype and over exaggeration. There is a sexual current running through the film, but it isn't anywhere near as deviant or shocking as some may make out. This film is more about one woman's development from a nave young adolescent, into a mature sexualised woman. Lee starts off by being unsure and shy and by the end of the film she is confident and sure of her feelings and wants out of life. This is slightly kooky and offbeat and Gyllenhaal turns out an excellent performance, managing to be by turns funny and kooky, sweet and innocent and sexy and self assured. All impressive stuff in what was one of her early movies. This has now become something of a minor cult film and if you enjoy unusual films and don't mind some risqu themes then this is well worth watching at some point.

The secretary is simply splendid and refreshing. I am glad to see a film that is unconventional, yet still has traces of a romantic comedy.  Lee (Maggie Gyllenhaal) is a cutter. She gives herself pain and in return gets pleasure from it. In the beginning of the film Lee gets out of the hospital and looks for a job. He starts working for a lawyer, Mr. Grey (James Spader). Mr. Grey himself has psychological issues having to do with control. Initially the relationship they have is sort of shocking, but you soon realize that it may actually be healthy. The issues that they have sort of come together to fit in a yin yang. They begin to complement each other.  Lee was a good role for Maggie Gyllenhaal. I think she did very well. I always enjoy watching James Spader's performances. He can act sophisticated and professional, yet crude and mean at the same time. He was also perfect in the movie Pretty and Pink. I recommend this film for the open minded. It is not a typical romance film. What I thought was so genuine to the characters was that it wasn't just the act of sex and affection that brought the lovers together, but a specific quality that brought Lee and Mr. Grey together.

One of those take it or leave it, hate it or love it movies, Secretary is an on the edge yet non-judgmental look at BDSM, or, to the squares out there, Bondage Domination Sadomasochism.

Innocent and self-destructive, and recently released from a psych ward, Lee Holloway (Maggie Gyllenhaal) self-mutilates to make up for her poor self-esteem and repressed sexual submissiveness.  After taking up typing she applies for a job as a secretary for E. Edward Grey (James Spader), an OCD lawyer with an apparently bustling law practice.  As the two grow to know one another, they learn a shared appreciation for an unorthodox physical, psychological, emotional attraction that transforms Lee from a pathetic girl next door into a more confident person and unleashes the creepy sadist sequestered inside Grey's calm demeanor.

Gyllenhall and Spader act perfectly, but I suspect it's because they're perfect for the role.  She conveys emotion perfectly in this role because she appears to be a person of great emotional fragility and considerable deferment.  On the other hand, Spader delivers every role in his own collected style that's a bit too good not to be partially truthful.  I can't imagine any other actor in either role.

Romantic and taboo at the same time, the plot flows well with some dark humor filling the gaps between BDSM scenes.  Beautifully filmed shots of long hallways in which secretaries must crawl to their master and hard desks on which delicious derrieres receive rosy handprints.  Highly recommended.

Jason Elin

Lee Holloway (Maggie Gyllenhaal) finds a job after her release from a mental hospital. She's shy and has a compulsive need to cut herself. Her boss, E. Edward Grey (James Spader) is also a bit nuts - angry outbursts at her pre-computer era typing errors that end up with him posting her errors on the wall, circled in red, spanking her, and her recognizing that she enjoys it. On the other hand, his more constructive efforts alleviate Lee's shyness, and she begins coyly pursuing him. This undermines her original attraction. Eventually he realizes they were made for each other. A bizarre romance.

The amazing thing about this movie is that it blends the human desire for sexual passion with our ultimate desire to find a soul mate on this earth who can embrace our deepest selves even at our dirtiest core--and more importantly bring validity to it. Mr. Grey has a problem with sexual dominance that causes him to run through secretaries very quickly while Lee, who comes to work for him is a confused young woman with an affinity for self-induced pain.

Eventually the two learn of each other's socially unacceptable quirks and come to satisfy each other's needs, which were prior to unfulfilling and incomplete. The S&M between both Lee and Mr. Grey is by no means centered on pornography, which would separate sexual desire from intimacy and is used simply for the means of erotic pleasure but rather an intimate and unique bond that corny as it sounds completes both Lee and Mr. Grey.  This is why Lee must tell Mr. Grey that she loves him and wants to make love to him--her feelings for him are not just erotic but centered on a deep and complex bond that can only be founded in love.

The ending is one for the hopeless romantic where the heroine, Lee has saved Mr. Grey with her relentless loyalty and complete devotion bringing him back to life and melting his once removed and icy heart as he romantically carries her upstairs to a private love making lair.

This is definitely a unique movie that you'll never forget and will probably have a strange love affair with. Both men and women can find something in this movie but as you've probably guessed is for the older crowd.

If you have never seen this movie you are missing a classic.  What an amazing story and it is acted out perfectly.  Ever wondered how far that co-worker would go?  Check this out, you will laugh and your senses (and other things possibly) will be aroused.

Enjoy.

When I think of erotic movies, I usually remember overstylized and heavy handed music video versions of movies that have little-to-no-understanding of how each particular lifestyle works.  The characters never feel like real people and their "exploration" into the kinky side of their sex lives comes across fake poses and clueless renderings--usually with bright lights and really loud music.  Since it's Hollywood, there has to be moment of "self-discovery" and/or "hitting bottom" before true, normal love prevails.  And they lived happily ever after.

I remember reading about Stanley Kubrick's research for his orgy scenes in his final film, EYES WIDE SHUT.  After studying Roman orgies and such, he wasn't sure how to write the scenes where Tom Cruise infiltrates a high society orgy.  How does such things really work?  The only thing that made that scene work were the masks.  The quasi-religious ritual of pairing up partners...not so much.

But then along comes SECRETARY.  And it works because it doesn't focus on the wild and kinky side of sex, but because it allows the kinks to come out of Real Characters.  Maybe that's why there are so few successful films about this (or any other) alternative lifestyle: the filmmakers are too fascinated by the acts than by the characters acting them out.

In the extras, the director said he wanted to make a film about a successful S & M relationship the way that the earlier film MY BEAUTIFUL LAUNDERETTE did for a gay relationship.  Mission accomplished.

The only reason I'm not giving this film 5 stars is that I couldn't track James Spader's character development as easily as I could Maggie Gyllenhaal's.  She is a genuine character who fully communicates everything visually and verbally and I was able to follow her.  Great actress, great part.  Spader was a little less defined.  As Maggie's character accepts and achieves her identity, I was wondering if Spader was as sure of his own sexual identity as the movie played out.

Knowing people in this particular lifestyle, I have to try and ascertain from where this particular bent comes from--and how it expresses itself.  Yes, it's different, but I know people who love this style of relationship and see it as another avenue of pleasure, not some sick, twisted acting out of dark, crazy mental/emotional ailment.  There's nothing wrong with them, they just enjoy this.  I find that interesting.  And SECRETARY tells their story.
WOW! This is one hot and unique movie. Not for children. The story line keeps you watching the movie.
If you enjoy love storys with a bit of a twist then this movie is for you.

this is one of the best films ive ever seen I love it.
i could watch it everyday.

JP

This is a very interesting portrayal of some aspects of the D/s BDSM lifestyle. Although in fact that almost appears to be on the periphery of the story. The reality is more about these two conflicted characters neither of whom fit well into the real world.
I did not find this to be a comedy even though it has some good comic elements.
Also I suspect many people who have reveiwed this here did not understand some parts of it.
Lee, the main character does cut herself, but it seems to be the way she has learned to escape the pain of her life. The release of endorphans from the cutting pain, helps her feel better.
Mr. Grey, the lawyer is truly a lost soul. I would have to even conclude that he suffers from Aspergers syndrome based on his behavior: He is bright, shy and has a difficult time relating to other people in a normal way. He is really a gentle person, even releasing mice caught in his office back outside. Growing orchids. He has trouble reconciling his quiet nature with his need for dominance in his relationships.
Therein lies the crux of the story.
Well done, sensual and fun. However without being familiar with or having read up on the BDSM lifestyle mny viewers may not really understand the story. There are many books on this on Amazon, including Consensual Spanking and others.
Many folks may find this film disturbing however, so choose carefully who you show it to.

The Bottom Line:

An interesting take on the boy-meets-girl tale (with a bit of spanking involved), Secretary is well-acted and heartily recommended to anyone who wants a movie that's a little different than the norm.

The movie itself was very good. There are some very sexy and emotive scenes. Great acting on the part of James Spader--he makes the film, in my opinion. Maggie Gyllenhall is also very well cast in this role. My only qualm is that this film associates BDSM with mental illness and emotional issues, implying that kink is the result of these problems.

For the mature, this is a delightfully delicious romp into the realm of fetish!  Maggie Gyllenhaal and James Spader are wonderfully teamed as two unusual people evolving into their greater selves.

While there were moments I reached for the remote...thinking I might wish to speed through what appeared to be too unseemly a reality, I never really had to press the button.  The movie stayed "tastefully" this side of cruel, while educating the viewer of the "lesser" needs of the desperate.

For all the unsavory subject matter, that I can dare to say that this is actually a "feel good" movie is the greatest compliment to everyone involved in the making of the film.  In less gifted hands, it could have easily gone over the line into repulsion.  But, everyone involved was/is a true artist in their own right, and we, the viewing public, are given the benefit of those skills.  For those wanting to expand their own borders, this is a fine movie to watch along the way.  You'll be glad you did! I highly recommend this film for the "mature" and the "evolving" soul.

Two emotionally wounded people find love through a dominant/submissive relationship.  Maggie Gyllenhahl is great, as usual.  Warning: although the domination scenes aren't that heavy, some people could find them offensive.  But I'm not into BDSM myself and still liked the movie a lot.
Good movie that takes you into a girls mind as give you a deeper peak.
The product I ordered arrived very quickly and in great condition.  I am a very satisfied customer.  :)

I'm not into blood and the cutting scenes with Maggie Gyllenhaal made me look away. This also starts v e r y slowly, and you might tune out before it really gets going, as I was tempted to do. In all, you'll have to work if you want to get through this one, so it's not a good choice for a night of easy viewing pleasure.

I'M YOUR SECRETARY! I'M YOUR SECRETARY! Punishingly funny. Sick, disturbing, entertainingly silly comedy. From subtle, to heavy-handed, to unpredictable.

You're not sure if you want to like, hate, or pity the main characters; Mr Grey (James Spader - Stargate, The Practice, Boston Legal) or Lee (Maggie Gyllenhaal - Donnie Darko, The Dark Knight). But there are some outrageous scenes that make up for the somewhat (ahem) sick sexual practices that the boss and secretary go through.

Jeremy Davies (Saving Private Ryan, Solaris, Rescue Dawn), as Lee's spaced-out boyfriend Peter, lends welcomed comic relief to some pretty dark and painful scenes (pun intended).

This movie is definitely not for the straight-laced; even though you've got to keep reminding yourself "It's only a movie."  Not be be taken seriously. The tomato throwing scene was priceless.
Good movie, kind of long though and more drama than action.  Maggie is very good in this movie.  I'd recommend it only for adults though, pretty provocative.

Normally I wouldn't watch such a movie, but I did. There are many themes layered throughout this movie that you could pull apart and inspect, or ignore, depending on your view. You could fixate yourself on the S&M aspect and be blind to everything else, unable to look past the red-rears and handcuffs.

I saw this movie as about a woman discovering who she is in a world she never knew existed. Yes, James Spader's character is a bit odd, dominating her with almost Nazi-like authority. But the girl holds herself, finding out how strong she really is and how much she can endure. It's about discovering what really drives you forward and makes you who you are. It's about being able to look passed what society thinks as normal and create your own world with your own rules.

The movie started a bit slow, then gradually picked up momentum. By the end I was so pulled into it I wanted more. A short "making of" segment and trailer are the only special features on this DVD. Not much else, but then again I couldn't imagine what more could be added.

Overall a great movie, fun for the whole family...especially the kids!!

In writing this review, I notice that the recommended tags are things like "BDSM" and "taboo," however this view of the movie really doesn't do it justice.  Neither is it done justice by the view of Mary Gaitskill that this is the "Pretty Woman" version of the short story this movie is based on.  "Secretary" is not a salacious Dom-sub movie, but it has cinematic qualities that recommend it as something more than a Hollywood romantic comedy.

From a set and costume perspective, this is one of the best movies I've ever seen.  Everything chosen for this film is textured, highly sensuous, and beautiful, and the cinematography is well crafted to show off the props without detracting from the story-telling.  The script is also well done with adequate dialog and good plot development.  I hadn't read anything about this film beforehand, I honestly didn't know how it was going to turn out right up til the end, and I wanted to find out!  There is only one really unfortunate choice--a video montage with a pop music soundtrack around 1:40:00 takes you out of the world the director has sucked you into.  But that is only one instance.

As for the Dom-sub theme, I was prepared to be turned off, but I was not.  Despite the theme, the movie is not sadistic in its treatment of the heroine.  It invites us to be sympathetic with her, and the James Spader character actually helps her stop one unhealthy and damaging clinical expression of psychopathology.  Whether the relationship that eventually develops between Gyllenhaal and Spader should be considered "healthy" (or is itself an expression of psychopathology) is something for psychologists and sexologists to debate among themselves, but "Secretary" does not invite us to leer at exploitation the way a film like "Boogie Nights" does.

This is not a film I would watch with my parents or children, or with hard-left feminists.  But I would watch it with friends or possibly a date (not the first).  If you are a film aficionado or if you enjoy off-beat films (like Tim Burton), you really need to see this one, although I think it could be enjoyed by just about anybody who doesn't have a knee-jerk reaction to the theme.

I finally saw this film. I've always liked Maggie Gyllenhaal (Mona Lisa Smile, etc.) and she carried this first lead role like a confident pro. Indeed, she was fine, as was James Spader, more in control than the roles for which he's known. My favorite of all, however, is Jeremy Davies. A very earnest and complete performance. Steven Shainberg has crafted a film that shocks, amuses, and finally leaves the audience with a happy feeling.

I found the movie to be very thought provoking in ref to human nature and how different people like different things in a relationship and sexually. And what brought them to that place. I think it is up for discussion with your partner. I liked it!

Like other reviewers, I rented "Secretary" because of Maggie Gyllenhaal, whose work over the years since 2003 meant that I had to go back and see "Secretary," knowing she probably bungee-jumped head first into this dangerous role.

I'm going to comment on the lasting impressions for me, not in order of importance:

I was thrilled by the brilliant moments when the characters (he and she) reached out to, and came to understand each other.  The world is a cold and lonely place for human beings because we all need affection and companionship.  But for many reasons, it is terribly difficult to find and connect with soul mates, let alone like minds.

I loved the scene when he explains why he thinks she is cutting herself and tells her she doesn't need to do it anymore.  At that moment, if only for a moment, she finally got the understanding and affection she desperately needed and deserved.  And although it didn't occur as suddenly, she definitely came to understand him and what he needed.

"Secretary" delivers the goods for those viewers with mostly prurient interests.  However, I thought the displays of physical intimacy between these two people who come to care for each other, unencumbered by what is generally accepted by society, was gracefully done. No, I don't mean the spanking or humiliation.  I mean, for example, the scenes of tenderness, like the one near the end when he worships every inch of her body (particularly one very special inch).

I enjoyed the tension and near anguish portrayed by the actors as they approached terrifying moments requiring all their courage.  Breaking through barriers, taking risks, and experimenting is scary.  I saw these two characters battle through walls of anonymity and loneliness to make a connection with each other.

Many narrow lines are walked in this movie.  The most important and dangerous of these lines, of course, was knowing when risky behaviors like these are selfless, tender examples of lovemaking, and when they are selfish, cruel exploitation.  In "Secretary," we are given many clues about it being the former, rather than the latter.  But do we really always know?  Of course not.  Did the characters always know?

I would have awarded five stars had the character development for the male lead been anywhere near what it was for her.  And I would have liked more balance between the two of them, in terms of giving and taking.  Its easier to see how the subservient role is giving to the dominant role than it is the other way around.  And there were moments when I laughed, but whenever I did, I felt I wasn't being honest to the drama.

(SPOILER WARNING.)  There is no question that this is one of the oddest love stories I have ever seen.  A young woman, with a quirky beauty that reveals itself over the course of the film, evolves from a self-mutilating mental patient to a fully realized and loving wife.  It is an extraordinary transformation, told in the form of comedy, and the viewer can believe it.

The acting is wonderful.  Spader is at his absolute best:  creepy, with bizarre tastes to say the least, yet full of need in a way that is understandable and increasingly vital.  From a rigid obsessive type, he becomes a man in search of love, even if it involves ropes and a saddle.  This is also Gyllenhaal's first starring role and she is magnificent.  The supporting characters from her hapless boy toy to her alcoholic father and co-dependant mother are also excellent.

As many have noted, this film had to tread an extremely fine line.  One the one hand, there is no question that the couple is perverted.  They indulge in pain, humiliation, and bondage.  On the other hand, though so wounded and inhibited, they forge a true relationship.  Their journey is moving, at times titillating, and even fascinating.

Warmly recommended.  The range of human behavior is forever unfathomable and unpredictable.  This film shows what a mystery life and the hope for love can be.

"Secretary" is my favorite movie of all time! I love everything about it! The two main characters, the story, the dialogue, the way it was shot, even the set decoration. I think it is a wonderfully romantic and erotic story that is very tastefully done. There are a lot of humorous parts too. It is refreshingly different from the typical romance. James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal are PHENOMENAL!

Quirky.  Funny.  Original.  Intellectual.

I appreciated the performances, the writing, and the overall storyline.

I never thought I'd like this movie by the previews when if first came out.  I happened to catch it on TV about a year ago and was hooked.  It's different from your typical love story but it's a love story nonetheless.  It's unusual and not for everyong but it shows you that there is a love out there for everyone, you just have to find it.  Not for the younger set though so be cautious.

It is hard to catergorise this film. Whether it is a romantic comedy, a black comedy, a drama or a sexual thriller there really is only one word I can use to describe it...Boring.
I bought this without seeing it for one reason and one reason only. Maggie Gyllenhaal... She is an amazing actress and I am a big fan of her talents and while I was expecting this movie to be left of centre, not even her performance could stop me from falling asleep in parts.
Its not that I bought this without knowing anything about it, I researched it and read many reviews, the storyline did interest me but I was just always waiting for the movie to get into it. James Spader is stale, as was the rest of the supporting cast. Two stars however for Maggie Gyllenhaal, who's performance alone will no doubt attract fans of hers to this film.

James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal definitely ignite the screen with the bizaar tale of a twisted, weaving S & M relationship. Two people who are made for each other, by chance, encounter one another when James (Mr Grey) hires Maggie as a secretary. Both feeding off of each others weaknesses Maggie suffers from cutting and unable to cure it in a mental hospital and James (Mr. Grey) who gets off on sadomasochism but doesn't want to be that way.  Both personalities compliment (or satisfy)
the others perverse desires and lead you through an original storyline that keeps you intrigued to the ending. A movie not for everyone but definitely entertaining and highly recommended.

I love James Spader - have since his teenage movie days into Less than Zero and then Sex, Lies & V / White Palace / Crash and so much more.  He is so adept in being able to portray real-life people and situations.

Big kudos to the writer/director for portraying a BDSM relationship as it is meant to be - consentual.  And with both parties aware of the roles and enjoying them.

Finally, but not last, a big plus also to Maggie Gyllenhall.  Great acting showing the evolution of her character from damaged to someone strong enough to be submissive to another person.  It takes a very strong character to be able to so do.

This is my favorite movie of all time.  No question.  Gyllenhaal and Spader deliver the most delicious, sensual, and innocent love story I have ever seen in film.  The cinematography is breathtaking and the plot is ground-breaking.  I do not imbibe in the S&M lifestyle, but this movie made me wish I did!  It is, without a doubt, the sweetest hard-core love story ever made.
My suggestion: Watch the movie once, then immediately watch it again with the sound off, so you can appreciate the beautiful staging and use of color without getting wrapped up in the dialogue again.  If you are not absolutely blown away by the opening scene, you need a CAT-scan.  My only complaint (which is hardly a complaint) is that there could have been a little more background on Mr. Grey.  I wish I could know a little more about his life before Lee, such as his ex-wife, the other secretaries, etc.  Other than that, this movie is flawless without being preening, passionate without being contrived, innocent without being trite, and so erotic without being overtly-sexual.  Watch it!  Watch it!  Watch it now!

In a few words....This is BRILLIANT acting!!! this movie has my undivided attention every time i watch it.
there are so many ways to interpret this movie - it keeps giving you more.

Secretary is a movie you will really like or really loathe. I am somewhere in the middle. The story of a girl who cuts herself and finds happiness in a sadomachism relationship with her pompous boss could turn most people off and I have to admit some of the scenes are pretty risque but Maggie Gyenhaal wins over the audience with her dark optimism and self-deprecting attitude. She falls in love with Edward played by James Spader, it's an unusual kind of love but it works for her, she is used to hurting herself and now she finds pleaure in Edward releasing that same pain on her. This movie is not for everyone but it is worth a viewing or two. Enjoy!

"Secretary" was my introduction to Maggie Gyllenhaal, and I have yet to see her in anything better.  Who is this woman?  I have a serious crush.  I had no prior knowledge about the actress or the movie, so her transformation mid-movie into this striking, poised, turned-on woman -- wearing shackles as she conducts her secretarial business with a smile on her face -- was a completely unexpected pleasure.  James Spader is right at home as the weird guy who turns out to be the perfect complement to this disturbed woman and the one person in her life who can bring out the best in her.  Their interplay reveals some truths about human nature that maybe only the adventurous and honest among us would admit they recognize.  S&M, per-se, certainly isn't everyone's cup of tea.  Still, there's something insightful about the success of their particular relationship.  I'd double-bill this with "The African Queen", or maybe a Tracy / Hepburn movie.

I loved this movie from the start. The way a young woman feels at that age is portrayed brilliantly by Maggie. The sexual tension that builds throughout the movie is a turn on. This movie relives my fairytales at finding true love and lust as a young woman. Absolutley my favorite movie

Wonderful movie.  Some of our puritanical American viewers might get stuck on the sexual content and reject this film (probably out of a sense of their own sexual inadequacies).  This movie goes much deeper than raw eroticism.  It is a wonderful commentary on individuality and the psychology of individuality. This film celebrates the uniqueness of the individual human spirit.  This film screams about acceptance and appreciation of oneself -- and to acknowledge and honor the normal and quirky traits we all possess.  This movie is truly a great film.  It will undoubtedly go down as an important cult classic -- I would argue on the same par as cult classics "The Graduate" and "Harold and Maude."  The performances by Maggie Gyllenhaal and James Spader are first rate.  These were likely too very difficult roles to pull off and they did it superbly.
Watch it with your significant other....you'll thank me!  I borrowed this from a friend and have no intention to return it.

DON'T BE DECEIVED BY THE COVER - NO STOCKINGS, NO HEELS.  ONE BRIEF SPANKING SCENE (no flesh included) is the highlight of the film.  Perhaps lifestylers would get nostalgic about this story, but for the curious weekend thrill seeker this DVD is sure to disappoint, if not get you 'shut out'.  Definitely not a couples movie unless your lady is VERY much into BDSM, in which case this would only be a 101 level course if not a grade school primer. Don't judge a DVD by its cover!!

James Spader must be one truly sexually disturbed man. Most of his work seems to revolve around men whose proclivities are far from healthy. From Crash to Sex, Lies, and Videotape, James Spader seeks out sexual encounters that are distant, shallow, and self-destructive as well as demeaning. He continues in good form here in a rather entertaining piece on sado-masochism. Sexual harassment be damned!

This is my favourite film of all time.  A perfectly dark comedy and strange fairy tale romance rolled into one, "Secretary" shocked and enraptured me from the start.  I couldn't ask for a more captivating storyline, carefully written script, complete character development, or perfectly executed performances!  You MUST see this film... ;}

Quirky, kinky, sensual, beautiful and fun!

James Spader and Maggie Gyllenhaal both have wonderful performances!  Steven Shainberg put together a great film with more substance then may be expected from a love story.  That said, be warned that if you are uncomfortable with the idea of bdsm being anything other then a sickness then "keep on walking" because this is not a movie for you.

One of the things I liked most was the depth of character development.  Gyllenhaal and Spader had fantastic chemistry and were able to pack so much emotion and communication in to simple expressions and gestures.  I can't say enough good things about the work they have done here.

As for the story, I LOVE IT!  Both Mr. Grey (Spader) and Lee (Gyllenhaal) start out in dark places.  Lee is drifting in life and has taken to cutting herself.  Mr. Grey is alone and disgusted with himself.  Both struggle with "unnatural" feelings and a sense of detachment, they just don't feel normal.  By the end they have learned that it is OK not to be normal so long as you are who and what you are.  They fine that together they are complete.  A very satisfying ending!

This is a movie that is not for everyone. It is rich in emotions and goes way beyound some people's comfort levels. But I enjoyed it because there was a such an amazing finale that shouted originality. The 2 stars are perfect together and you totally want them to end up together. Maggie takes a job as a secretary- she has extreme self esteem problems and was just released from an institution. She starts working for Spader and he goes completely nuts when she makes even the most trivial mistakes and starts his own form of wierd erotic punishment. Most people would freak out but she starts to want it- and thus we have the start of a beautiful relationship full of wierdness. This is a love story and it is one of my faves because it is just soo different and lovely.

If you are a fan of James Spader then you should totally see this, and if you haven't seen Maggie Gyllenhaal you NEED to see this. I left this movie wanting to see it again and again.

This darkly comic yet compelling BDSM-light relationship is blessed with great performances by Maggie Gyllenhaal and James Spader.  The script is well-written; little personal moments in the film are beautifully shot, and the actors really find the soul of the characters they portray.

At its heart, it's really a sweet (if slightly disturbing) romance where one person's *unique* need for control meets up beautifully with someone else's *unique* need to submit.

Sexy?  YES.  Disturbing?  A LITTLE.  Worth watching?  ABSOLUTELY.

If you like unusual films, odd love stories, and quirky characters, this is a must-see.

Secretary doesn't seem like the type of movie that would warrant much attention. At a closer inspection we find out that it has the potential for greatness written all over it. Maggie Gyllenhal does a tremendous job as the lead in this film, she definitely left me wanting to see more of her.

My first viewing of the campy film Secretary could not have been more ironic because I had been working as a secretary -- ahem, assistant -- for a solo practitioner for only two months. I recall leaving the theater feeling empowered despite knowing that the next day I would have to fetch whatever my boss wanted, when he wanted it. There are bosses, not just the lawyers, who long for the old-fashioned secretary.

Bravo to the filmmaker for rendering Secretary's unflinching revelations about emotional pain as unsettling as its erotic depictions of the catharsis of that pain. I found, and still find, the film to be a surreal and vicarious pleasure. Not that what ensues between the boss and assistant in Secretary is unrealistic. Perhaps you know of a solo proprietor whose temp secretaries kept quitting but who now has a full-time assistant. Why is that assistant a perfect match?

Intellectually, I admire the filmmaker's courage in commenting poetically upon the ways in which American society conditions women to be passive and to devalue themselves. Leave it to an art/indie film to expose how some (or many?) American women find themselves either stuck in a time warp of adolescent vanity or suffering through existential paralysis. Because American women are taught to identify and value themselves through their relationships with men, it is a total thrill in Secretary to watch the script flip the stereotype of the skirt-chasing boss on its head.

In terms of casting, I cannot imagine anyone but Maggie Gyllenhaal in the title role. Her secretary is like the repressed alter ego of Elizabeth Taylor's Maggie the Cat on that hot tin roof -- full of angst but no less smoldering. Maggie G. appears to purr rather than speak. James Spader, who once upon a time seemed typecast as a snooty yuppie, gets the chance in Secretary to fully realize his erotic potential. While his character can be viewed as tongue-in-cheek, he delivers a genuinely quirky and sensitive performance.

When you get down to it, the various vicarious experiences in Secretary will please some and repulse others. For me, I received instant motivation to strive for accuracy in transcribing my boss's future dictation.

romantic, dreamy, and wonderfully done.

the father figure still sucks though.

I loved the edginess of this movie, it's not for middle america for sure, but if you are somewhat off of center you'll get it and really enjoy it.  Gyllenhall was awesome, her performance makes me want to see everything she's ever done.  The movie has a big heart and a nicely perverse sense of humor.
I lived this movie.  I love the fact that she was a cutter like me and then found BDSM and stopped cutting!  It has a great plot as well.
